title: eu chief waste time brexit red lines
story: We welcome Ursula von der Leyen being “ambitious” about striking a new, “unprecedented” trade deal with “zero tarfs and zero quotas”.We too want to remain “the best of friends and partners”. But we implore Brussels not to expend energy hoping to erode Boris Johnson’s Brexit red lines.Without them he would not have his -seat majority. And he simply has no desire to soften Brexit. Britain will not be bound by Brussels.Yes, goods will flow less freely at our borders. That is the price of freedom and the many new opportunities this Government, unlike the last, looks ­genuinely keen to exploit.Even Remainers like Bank of England chief Mark Carney and ex-Chancellor George Osborne say our hands must not be tied by EU regulations over finance.For Boris that holds true for everything  too.THE IRA, Putin, now Qasem Soleimani. Without fail, Corbyn takes our enemies’ side.It’s not hard to condemn Soleimani as a terrorist. It’s not “siding with Donald Trump” to do so. But Corbyn can’t.What concerns him is not eliminating the architect of Iran’s slaughter across the Middle East — the monster who killed British and US troops. It’s ­Soleimani’s rights under international law — and Trump’s potential “illegality”.Such are the warped values of the man who could have become our PM. Who took money to broadcast on the state TV channel of a rogue regime that executes gay men.Who is, incredibly, rated “ten out of ten” as leader by wannabe successor Rebecca Long Bailey.Millions deserted Labour because, among many other reasons, they saw that its leaders loathe Britain. title: mps cheer brexit passes
story: The Prime Minister third reading for the  Brexit bill passed by  to  votes, a majority of .The  vote win is a huge result for the Prime Minister, who ran his whole election campaign on a promise to “Get Brexit Done”.The massive majority came despite Labour, the Lib Dems and the SNP all opposing it.It means Britain is finally on the way to leaving the EU this month, with now just the Lords standing in the way of the UK’s departure.It came as MPs demanded Brexit beers and a massive celebration on January .Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay was facing Brexit questions this morning, and Conservative MPs couldn’t wait to share their party plans for the historic day.Polish-born MP Daniel Kawczynski called for celebrations to take place both in Britain and all over Europe.Addressing the Brexit secretary, he said: “The st of January is not just a signicant day for us here in the United Kingdom, but also for hundreds of millions of eurosceptics across the continent of Europe.“Does he agree with me it’s very important for us to celebrate this day very publicly as a nation to give a guiding principle to others in Europe that there is le outside the European Union.”Mr Johnson’s spokesman said: “The PM made it a priority to win a majority to get Brexit done and to move the country forward.“Securing the legislations passage through the Commons will be a signicant positive step to delivering upon that.”MPs were also planning what booze to knock back as we finally leave, with Tory MP Kate Grfiths calling for a special Brexit pint.The Burton MP said: “Would my right honourable friend agree that to mark us leaving the European Union, our fantastic local breweries in Burton-on-Trent should brew a celebratory Brexit beer.”Mr Barclay responded: “Mr Speaker from the reaction of the house my honourable friends strikes an extremely positive note in one of her first contributions.“I know her constituency is famed for its beer and am sure many members of this house would welcome them celebrating this occasion in such a way, just as I will do myself at the with a fantastic Elgoods brewery, which sits in my own constituency.”There were also calls for the British flag to be flown all over the country.Tory MPs rejoiced with veteran Eurosceptic Bernard Jenkin tweeting: “NOW we can stop banging on about Europe.”Sir John Hayes MP said: “In celebration of this important occasion in our nations history, I wonderthe Secretary of State will arrange for union flags to be flown from all public buildings across our kingdom.“That would be a fitting tribute to the decision that the British people made to leave the European Union.”The vote is a landmark moment in Britain’s history, leaving just one stage left at the House of Lords before the UK finally gets out on January .Unlike the flurry of failed votes under Theresa May, the result is in no doubt after Mr Johnson landed a stonking majority in the Christmas election.This will see it then head to the Upper chamber next week, with the Lords tipped to sign everything off by January .The Prime Minister will then try and negotiate a bumper trade deal, which he has insisted can be completed by the end of the year.He conducted crunch talks with new EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen yesterday, who outlined plans for an ambitious deal.However, the Eurocrat dismissed the idea this could be done in a year, and refused to rule out a further delay.She said: Without an extension of the transition period beyond  you cannot expect to agree on every single aspect of our new partnership. We will have to prioritise.A Downing Street spokeswoman said: The PM reiterated that we wanted a broad free trade agreement covering goods and services, and co-operation in other areas.The PM was clear that the UK would not extend the Implementation Period beyond  December  and that any future partnership must not involve any kind of alignment or ECJjurisdiction.

title: meghan harry miserable media toxic

title: loud snoring caused by fat tongue
story: The link was found in patients with mild to severe obstructive sleep apnoea, which leads to snoring, and a body mass index over .Those that lost weight found their sleeping improved by nearly a third.MRI scans showed a reduction in tongue fat volume was the key.Researcher Professor Richard Schwab said: “Most experts have not typically focused on fat in the tongue. but will still be guarded by taxpayer-funded bodyguards.Insiders now say Prince Harry has “completely changed” since meeting Meghan - said to be the driving force behind their choice.The Queen, Prince Charles and Prince William reportedly learned of Harry and Meghans decision when the news broke on TV.Harry has now been called to crisis talks with his family while Meghan has headed back to Canada to rejoin baby Archie.He is said to have left the Queen deeply distressed by his sensational announcement.No other members of the Royal Family were consulted before the shock statement was issued on Wednesday and the hurt Monarch was taken by surprise.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what is national minimum wage uk
story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to £..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to £., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: brexit key dates 2019 timeline

story: NewsBarry Gardiners Labour leadership hopes collapse in  hours as MP doesnt standThe Shadow Trade Secretary announced he was considering standing for the leadership on Wednesday night. Then, on Thursday night, he announced that he wouldnt stand after allShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsBarry Gardiner with outgoing leader Jeremy Corbyn and leadership candidate Emily Thornberry " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBarry Gardiner has announced he will NOT stand for Labour leader -  hours after he said he might. The Shadow Trade Secretary last night thanked MPs, activists and members of the public who encouraged him to stand for the top job. But he admitted heaposd be unable to get the  MP and MEP nominations he needed by the Monday deadline. I have therefore decided not to stand for the leadership at this time, Mr Gardiner declared. The statement closes the most unexpected episode of the Labour leadership contest, which erupted on Wednesday night while Mr Gardiner was at a climate conference in Abu Dhabi. HuffPost UK broke the surprise news that he could become the seventh candidate - despite MPs already giving dozens of nominations to frontrunners Keir Starmer and Rebecca Long-Bailey. Mr Gardiner then confirmed his intentions to the Mirror himself down the phone from the Middle East. Iaposm considering it because I believe I would have the best chance of winning at a general election and making sure we get a Labour government, he declared. Yet even as he launched a possible campaign from thousands of miles away, the six existing candidates were scooping up votes . More than two thirds of Labour MPs,  out of , have now declared their support for a candidate - narrowing the pool who could have nominated Mr Gardiner by .pm on Monday. Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer is in the lead with  nominations while Corbyn alliesapos favourite Rebecca Long-Bailey has .  Outspoken backbenchers Jess Phillips and Lisa Nandy also crossed the line last week with  and  nominations. Emily Thornberry and Clive Lewis look set to struggle, however - with just  and  nominations respectively. Mr Gardiner said: I want to thank all my colleagues as well as the party activists and members of the public who encouraged me to stand for the Labour Leadership. I am now clear that at this late stage I cannot secure sufficient nominations to proceed to the next round. I have therefore decided not to stand for the leadership at this time. I will continue to serve the party loyally under whichever of my colleagues has the honour of leading our party forward to win the next General Election.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Prince Harry and Meghan’s decision to quit as senior royals is a “family squabble”, according to Donald Trump ’s man in Britain.US Ambassador Woody Johnson backed the Queen over the row which has rocked Buckingham Palace, saying the President “couldn’t have a higher opinion of her Majesty”. Ambassador Johnson told LBC: He is just so impressed with what she has been able to achieve. She [The Queen] has had a lot of problems over the years and she has come out very well in all of them. The USaposs man in London added that getting a deal the pair can live with was in everyoneaposs interest but said, it is up to the family about how they want to handle it. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have vowed to split their time between the UK and North America having decided they want to opt-out of royal le. The Home Office and Foreign Office will be involved in working out how the pair’s wishes can be accommodated - but yesterday ex-Chancellor Philip Hammond warned it would be more complicated than the pair have imagined. Mr Hammond, told Emma Barnett on Radio Live yesterday: it’s very dficult for people who are senior members of the royal family to have careers in the ordinary sense of the word. He said he wasnapost surprised about the decision but said there would be challenges. He continued: I think it will be very dficult for them, and I’m sure they understand the pressures and dficulties that they will face because every single thing that they do, or try to do, will come under immense scrutiny.  So, on the one hand, it’s very commendable that somebody in that position wants to try to earn their own living. It’s also only fair that we recognise that the intense interest that the media and the public opinion will take in everything that they do will make it actually quite dficult for them to do so. Earlier in the day the Sussexes faced criticism after it emerged they had pledged to remain in their home - which was renovated at the taxpayers expense.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailNorthern Irelandaposs three-year political deadlock could finally be coming to an end after the UK and Irish governments published a draft deal to restore power-sharing in Belfast. The Assembly at Stormont - Northern Irelandaposs seat of power - will be recalled on Friday to seeparties sign up. Northern Ireland Secretary Julian Smith, the third Tory minister to work on a deal, announced the late-night breakthrough yesterday. If agreed, it means Northern Irish politicians will finally have a full say over their own affairs once again. And it will mean Northern Ireland gets a major financial package from the UK government. It comes exactly three years since the devolved government collapsed following the resignation of late deputy first minister Martin McGuinness. The Assembly failed tosince, with neither unionists DUP or nationalists Sinn Fein - who must agree to share power under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement - able to compromise. While it lay in ruins, MPs at Westminster stepped in and legalised gay marriage and abortion in the region - with the first same-sex unions expected in the week of Valentineaposs Day. Northern Ireland Secretary Julian Smith announced the plans alongside Irish Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney at a press conference outside the grand Stormont building on Thursday night. He said he had asked the speaker of the defunct house to hold a sitting on Friday morning, without the Stormont parties having yet agreed to all the proposals. The DUP, the party blamed by both governments for holding up a deal in December, responded positively to the text - called aposNew Decade, New Approachapos. Party leader Arlene Foster said there was a basis to re-establish the devolved institutions in a fair and balanced way. All eyes now turn to Sinn Fein, whose president Mary Lou McDonald said: We are studying the text and will give it careful consideration. It is understood that smaller parties including SDLP, Ulster Unionists and Alliance Party were also involved in talks although it is not known how much influence they have had. The last DUP Sinn Fein-led coalition government collapsed in January  over a row about a botched green energy scheme. That dispute subsequently widened to take in more traditional wrangles on matters such as the Irish language and the thorny legacy of the Troubles. Now is decision time, Mr Smith said as he stood in front of Parliament Buildings on Thursday night. We have had three years of talks, finally there is good deal on the table that all parties can support and on that basis I have tonight written to the speaker of this Assembly and asked him to recall it tomorrow to enable the restoration of the executive before the weekend. I urge all parties to come here tomorrow and serve the people of Northern Ireland.  Power-sharing talks in Northern Ireland were held up repeatedly while crisis raged in Westminster - including a general election which made the DUP kingmakers in . But critics of Boris Johnson say his Brexit deal and thumping majority now represent a clear threat to the current way of le which Northern Ireland politicians must address. The deal claims it will bring Northern Ireland out of the EU aposwhole and entireapos with the rest of the UK. But because Northern Irelandaposs fragile coalition relies on free trade with the Republic of Ireland, compromises have had to be made to keep that open.

After her flight had already been delayed, one customer was temporarily refused entry onto the plane after boarding staff spotted her passport hadnapost been signed. Not knowing it required her signature, the already delayed line was forced to wait as she completed the necessary requirements on her passport - and she wasnapost happy about it. Taking to Twitter , she wrote: FFS British Airways flight is  mins late because the first officer was stuck in traffic to the airport. Despite that, gate staff refused to let me on the flight because my passport wasn’t signed. So instead we held up the queue for another  minutes while I practised my signature. She later added: Then, with the weight of tutting behind me, I scribbled any old s***e in my passport. So now for the next . years I have a sig that looks nothing like mine in my passport. Thanks British Airways, that’s not improved security in any way while storing up future problems for me. Rather than the apology so many companies have ready to fire out at any given moment on social media, BA staff member Angela responded to back up her colleagues at the gate, as reported by News.au . There are times when we have to accept responsibility for our own actions, she replied. If you’d signed your passport when you received it, this wouldn’t have become an issue. Angela.  The comeback ided opinion online, with some loving Anglelaaposs no nonsense approach. Angela @British_Airways deserves a raise, wrote one. “Well, that told you!” replied a second. That’s an awful apology, said one.

I just thoughtI ask [for money] Iaposll look like Iaposm failing and Iaposm trying to have my head above water and hold a facade so I knew this was my only option. Iaposm sorry cause I know Iaposve hurt you. Iaposve felt guilty all the time and Iaposm gonna have to live with it.  Collier said she knows she should have stopped, but just could not get a grip on it. She said: I havenapost been able to manage my money for a while. Like I said Sammy I wasnapost thinking and I was being selfish and at the time of me doing it I didnapost put you into consideration and itaposs disgusting but I have felt guilty once Iaposve done it. I know I shouldaposve stopped a long time ago. I just couldnapost get a grip on it. I just felt too proud to ask. I felt like a failure asking and that was my stupid decision to make.  Collier pleaded guilty to five counts of burglary and one count of theft. She was jailed on Tuesday for two nights while Judge Paul Watson QC, Honorary Recorder of Hull considered her punishment. She ed to Hull Crown Court on Thursday, and before she learned her fate, a victim impact statement, written by Miss Wood was read to the court. In the statement, Miss Wood said Collieraposs crime had an impact on her both mentally and physically which was a greater impact than she expected.  She described Collier as not only a friend, but a confidant, and someone who was like a family member to her and who her and her son loved and trusted. She said when Collier stole from her, she took food from the table and made it dficult for her to pay for bills. A victim impact statement from the elderly coupleaposs daughter , which was not read to the court was said to say the entire family were devastated to discover she was the thief. Judge Paul Watson QC suspended Collieraposs sentence for  months and she walked free from court.  He said the fact it was her first offence and that she had showed remorse and the fact there is little chance of her re-offending, he could suspend the sentence. Collieraposs war-hero granddad, who has not been named, died before Collier apologised and did not see her convicted. Speaking after sentencing, Miss Wood said she is just glad it is all over.

title: harry two strong women life
story: NewsopinionHarry had two strong women in his le - and he chose Meghan over the QueenThe Queen protected Harry and William after the death of their mother Princess Diana. She was criticised for looking after the poor boys instead of mourning in publicShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  JAN NewsopinionThe Queen was drawn to Harrys impish sense of humour " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn the early hours of August , , the Queen sat in her dressing gown at Balmoral Castle beside a sobbing Prince of Wales. They had just been informed, via a call from Paris, that Princess Diana had been killed in a car crash. Despite being numb with shock, the monarch’s first thought was to protect her grandsons William and Harry, whose lives were about to implode. She persuaded Charles to wait until morning before breaking the shattering news and ordered that all radios, TVs and newspapers be removed to shield the young princes. Then, rather thanto London to mourn with her subjects, she stayed closeted in her castle and tried to support “those poor boys”. It was one of the rare occasions when the Queen put family before duty – yet it led to a national outcry and accusations that she was distant, unfeeling. But it also sparked a touching new relationship with Diana’s boys and a special affinity with -year-old Harry, so patently damaged by his mother’s death. “Granny” became the most important female role model in his le until he met his future we Meghan. His nanny Tiggy-Legge Bourke was the cuddly surrogate mum – but the Queen was a counsellor, adviser and inspiration. She shared his love of country pursuits, his passion for the military and his impish sense of humour. Who can forget them both glowing with pride at Harry’s Sandhurst passing- out ceremony in  or the cheeky looks between them in the video he persuaded her to make to promote his Invictus Games in   “I absolutely adore my grandmother,” he said in an interview marking her th birthday, “but I always view her as the Queen – the boss.” When viewing footage of the -year-old Princess Elizabeth pledging her le to the service of the Commonwealth, he declared: “It’s a hugely moving speech.  “It’s incredible to know that someone at that age appreciated and understood exactly what was expected of them. To basically put duty ahead of everything  so early in her le is quite remarkable.” But Harry seemed to have an equally strong sense of duty, serving his country in the Army then forging a role as a Commonwealth Youth Ambassador with his new bride Meghan Markle . Ah yes – Meghan, the “breath of fresh air” we all took to our hearts when we saw how she had captured Harry’s. The orced, mixed-race, US actress and humanitarian who would aid the monarchy’s modernisation and give Harry the family and sense of purpose he craved. No wonder the Queen looked so delighted when the Duke and Duchess introduced her to their baby Archie. Poor lost Harry had found his other half, his happy ever after. So how can it be that, eight months on, he appears to have totally lost the plot  How could he have defied his Granny – his “boss” – with such callous disregard for her feelings, not to mention those of his father and brother  The -year-old Queen is left feeling angry, wounded and betrayed by the Sussexes’ arrogant attempt to create their own brand of royalty.  A move apparently prompted by the pair’s perception that Meghan has been “bullied”, “hounded” and “vilied”. When it looks to be more about her need to own the limelight, rather than take second billing to future Queen Kate and for them both to make a fortune out of Hollywood-style celebrity status while playing at saving the planet. Harry is so besotted with his older, charismatic, psychobabble-spouting we that it seems his personality is subsumed into hers. This fun-loving bloke has become the Prince of Woke and, while Meghan may have opened his eyes to many important issues, you can’t help feeling he has lost his sense of self. A former friend of his told me: “We all know people who’ve met a new partner and begun to distance themselves from old pals and relatives, becoming part of the other’s circle. “But when Meghan got engaged to Harry she cut herself off from family and old mates – and the only friends at their wedding were her A-list celebrity ones. “Now she and Harry are cutting themselves off from his family – yet expect to keep all perks and privileges, because being royal is their big selling point.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrince Harry and Meghan hatched their secret plot to leave the royal family on their last official tour in Africa. The couple held a series of heart-to hearts after agreeing they “couldn’t continue under the microscope of royal le”. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex put their plan into overdrive in the last six weeks after speaking to advisors linked to Hilary Clinton and Oprah Winfrey, before pressing the nuclear button on their royal careers. They kept the developments from the Queen, Prince Charles and Harry’s brother William while enlisting the help of a select band of advisors in the UK and America. The result to effectively resign from ‘The Firm’ and announce their new path without consultation has been met with “dismay and fury” inside the palace walls.  A well placed palace source said: “This all stems from their tour in South Africa. “Harry was the driving force behind it and was adamant there was no way back. He saw Meghan was struggling and told her he didn’t want to do another tour with the press and they would go their own way. “Meghan had already made the moves with contacts in America to launch their ‘brand’ and provided the avenue for it to happen. “After just  months of marriage, it was decided they couldn’t continue under the microscope of royal le and would leave on their terms.” The couple stopped communicating with their press team in the UK and instead launched their strategy to ditch their royal roles opening the door for them to earn millions in the corporate world. Sources say they will now split their time between the UK and Canada and are even considering home schooling their eight month old son Archie when he is ready. They have suggested they will dramatically scale down the number of official royal engagements on behalf of the Queen and instead turn the focus onto developing their personal foundation. Here we look at the obstacles that may face them as their embark on their new royal le: MONEY:    Harry and Meghan are worth £million in their own right and yet still received public funds from the Sovereign Grant. Harry was left £ million from his late mum Princess Diana’s estate and around £million from the Queen mother when she died. He also receives an yearly allowance from Prince Charles while Meghan was a successful TV actress before she met Harry. The Sovereign Grant is collected from the profits of Queen’s property portfolio - the Crown Estate - which are paid to the Government. Twenty-five per cent of these profits are paid to the monarchy to fund the upkeep of its property, travel, security and staff.  More than £. million was used from fund to do up their lavish Frogmore Cottage home, while the run their offices and pay for their travel on official engagements. The couple still plan to carry out some engagements on behalf of their team but have not yet devised a way of paying for it - unless they start signing mega-money deals with big corporations. Harry also receives up to £.million annually from his father’s royal estate, the Duchy of Cornwall. Palace aides have refused to say whether he will continue to take the money, which suggests the couple’s claims of being “financially independent” are far from clear. Senior palace sources say there is “huge implications of them entering the corporate world on their own accord” and the couple have not explained how they see this working. SECURITY:    Meghan and Harry have “failed to answer the simplest of questions” relating to their security provision, according to well places sources. They expect they will keep their state-funded politan Police protection officers who are paid for by the Home Office - with the bill topping £,-a-year. With overtime, travel and accommodation expenses this would likely reach £million. The issue of the Sussexes splitting their time between the UK and North America has given “major headaches ” to government departments on both sides of the Atlantic. Again, it is understood Harry and Meghan have not come up with suggestions as to how their security would be paid for. THE ADVISORS:  The couple have been working with the controversial US PR company Sunshine Sachs and will launch the Sussex Royal Foundation in the coming months. They employed the Clinton’s former communications advisor, American Sara Latham, last year. Despite her being a trusted and valued member of their team it is understood she was left out of key developments in the Sussexes’ plan to quit the royal family. Sources suggest she is considering her future role in the set up. Harry and Meghan also hired social media guru David Watkins, who previously worked with Burberry and Apple. THE MEDIA   SOCIAL MEDIA:  With an Instagram following of more than  million, Harry and Meghan plan to change the way they interact with royal fans. They have announced they will no longer participate in the official royal rota arrangement, agreed by the Queen and other senior royals as a way of publicising their good causes and engagements. This means they have cut out all UK media from following their work at home and abroad, choosing instead to work with publications and brands who agree to publish only favourable articles infor access. GLOBAL FAME:    PR gurus have told the couple they can become “one of the most influential couples in the world”. They have the potential to earn millions off the back of their royal titles, while suggesting they want to dramatically scale back their work at home. Harry has already worked on a mental health documentary series with Oprah set to be screened by Apple while Meghan has worked on clothing charities and guest edited British Vogue.  But palace insiders have questioned how the couple can realistically straddle the corporate and royal world when they will be potentially earning millions and continuing to represent the Queen on official engagements. Sources suggest in its current format the Sussexes’ plan “represents a massive conflict of interests and will no doubt cause problems for the reputation of the family”.

The Afghan war veteran was made Captain General of the elite Corps last year, replacing Prince Philip, but Royal Navy sources say his role is now “in doubt.” Harry who joined the Blue and Royals in  and served twice Afghanistan - first as a forward air controller and then as an Apace pilot has always been keen on the Royal Marines. His promotion to Captain General came after he served alongside  Commando in Helmand Province and was later invited by the green berets to open a new base at Plymouth. The appointment had been viewed by top brass as a ‘brilliant move’ that would attract young men and women to join the Marines. Since taking up the post Harry has visited the Commando Training base, joined them in action during war-games in Norway and spent a day with SBS special forces in their killing house at Poole, in Dorset. One told the Daily Mirror: “A lot of lads were not impressed that he was just given a beret and his commando badges yet he did nothing for them , not one run, nothing. He won’t be missed.  “His Dad who heads the paras underwent the jumps the course before the Army would let him wear wings, yet we just gave our beret and badges away”: Doubt over his future as ceremonial head of the Royal Marines could also lead to questions over his other honorary roles - as a Squadron Leader in the RAF and a Lieutenant Commander in the Navy.

story: NewsRAF hero, , left on trolley for  hour in crisis-hit NHSStan ­Solomons, who served in the RAF during the Second World War, was taken to Leicester Royal Infirmary where he waited hours for careShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsStan Solomons waited  hours on a trolley at Leicester Royal Infirmary" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt’s approaching midnight inside Leicester Royal Infirmary, and -year-old RAF hero Stan ­Solomons is still waiting on a ­trolley. He’s been here for almost  hours, admitted to AE via ambulance at around midday. Stan, who trained at the ­codebreakers’ HQ Bletchley Park during the Second World War and went on to serve with the RAF and later at a ‘listening post’ in Hong Kong, is not one to complain, but his feet are hanging off the edge of the trolley. “I grew up in the years before the NHS was set up, when healthcare was ‘hit and miss’,” Stan says. “My ­generation built the NHS to take the worry out of being ill, and to make sure that everyone has access to good quality healthcare.” Yesterday shocking new figures showed a record collapse in ­emergency care across the NHS – with Stan just one of tens of thousands of people left on trolleys. In December, the number of people waiting four hours or more on hospital trolleys reached , while , people waited more than  hours. Both figures are the highest on record. Stan is at pains to stress how “caring the staff are and how hard they work for their patients”. But he says they are “overworked and stressed”.Health Secretary Matt Hancock visited the hospital on December  – the day before the general election – to “see the impact that the new AE has had, just incredible impact”.But by December , when Stan faced his -hour ordeal, the election was over and the spotlight had faded.Election victor Prime Minister Boris Johnson was already on a £,-a- week holiday on the private island of Mustique. Some , miles away back home, Stan lay on a trolley. Born in , he grew up in the East End of London. “He was evacuated during the war, but like many children ed just in time for the doodlebugs,” his daughter Rachael Ellis, a social worker, says. “His own home experienced bomb damage with Stan and his family living in half a house until they could move where.” Stan has had an ­incredible le, eventually becoming a teacher, studying for a PhD in retirement and has been married for  years to Bette. But now, he needs the support of the NHS. On December , paramedics rushed him to hospital after he became very unwell with a suspected infection. He was admitted to AE just before midday. From .pm until pm there was a power cut, caused by an underground cable fault, which meant some ambulances were erted to other hospitals and that some equipment couldn’t be used. “AE was packed, with people sitting on the floor,” says Stan’s ­granddaughter Roxanne Ellis, a Labour and Co-operative councillor. “Staff were having not only to reassure distressed patients and family members but also cope without  their usual back up and information.  “We were told there was no bed available for Stan. He was fth on the list of older people waiting for a bed and th overall. While Stan did not complain – that’s not in his nature – he was clearly very uncomfortable. “The trolley wasn’t long enough, his feet were hanging over the edge and he kept sliding further down needing assistance to get back. Meanwhile, he was steadily getting more poorly and became delirious. “We don’t want to criticise NHS staff, who in our view were doing an amazing job under very dficult circumstances. The only reason the NHS hasn’t failed has been due to the overwhelming commitment of the staff.” Jonathan Ashworth MP, Labour’s Shadow Health Secretary, is also the local MP for Leicester Royal Infirmary. “Stan’s case is yet another heart-breaking example of how our NHS has been plunged into total crisis under the Tories,” he says. “Years of cutbacks mean unacceptable misery for patients like Stan who deserve so much better. “The worst AE figures on record and almost , patients waiting on trolleys is a badge of shame for the Tories.

story: NewsFour-star hotel caught offering smoked baby chimpanzee on menu for £Hotel owner André Kadima claims the dish appeared on the menu without his knowledge and was included due to a printing errorShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe dish was reportedly being sold on the menu for £" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA four-star hotel in Africa has allegedly been caught offering smoked baby chimpanzee on its à la carte menu. The dish - bébé chimpanzé fumé - was reportedly being served for £ at The Beatrice Hotel, in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo . However, the business is now facing criminal proceedings after an animal conservation charity Conserv Congo expressed its horror.Adams Cassinga, charity group director, claimed the hotel was serving smoked chimpanzee to appeal to its growing Asian clientele and wealthy local diners looking for a potent dish, reports The Times. He added: People believe you can consume the spirit of an animal through its flesh and carry it around to make you appear more powerful. It is popular with politicians, policemen and curious foreigners.” Conserv Congo has made a formal complaint against the hotel, alleging it has traded in a protected species. Management initially denied that it was offering chimp on its menu. But hotel owner André Kadima later admitted that it had been included without his knowledge.  However, he denied that the animal was ever being cooked at the establishment and said it was a printing error. He told The Times: “I was away when it was printed and when I got back I immediately ordered that it be destroyed and reprinted. We don’t sell cooked chimpanzees. I love chimpanzees and know how valuable they are to our wildle.”

title: mystery humming noises heard around
story: NewsMystery humming noises heard around the world from underwater volcano, scientists sayA study has found the low hum was caused by the formation of a new underwater volcano in the Indian Ocean off the coast of the island of Mayotte, near MadagascarShareCommentsByTalia Shadwell:,  JAN NewsThe strange noises puzzled the worlds scientic community " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailScientists have finally solved the mystery of what was causing strange noises heard around the world. Experts had been baffled by the bizarre seismic aposhummingapos sounds heard by earthquake monitoring agencies around the globe in . The signals were picked up in May and June of that year, and another in November that lasted up to  minutes. The tremors linked to the noises were traced to the island of Mayotte in the Indian Ocean, one of four volcanic islands in an archipelago located between Africa and Madagascar. Scientists working on the case now say they have discovered the cause of the sounds that aroused curiosity among the worldaposs scientic community. Their study found the formation of a new underwater volcano caused thousands of tectonic quakes that triggered the unusual noises.The findings were published in the journal Nature Geoscience this week.A monotone aposringapos was noted by a New Zealand-based quake enthusiast in November , who noticed unusual readings from the US Geological Survey. The unusual seismic signal was recorded at Kilima Mbogo, Kenya an could be seen all around the world, the expert wrote. The post sparked a heated debate amongst the community as waves were detected in Chile, New Zealand, Canada and Hawaii. The unusual signals were initially discounted as earthquakes because it lasted for too long and because of its global spread. But others pointed out the same region had recorded a cluster of quakes, particularly around May that year. The mystery led to heated debates among the scientic community around the world. Researchers from the German Research Centre for Geosciences GFZ used new seismological methods to trace the odd noise.  They traced , tectonic quakes detected over a period of a year in the study investigating the phenomenon. These types of tremors occur when the the Earthaposs tectonic plates become stuck as they move alongside on one another. They found there had been a magnitude . shake near Mayotte in May - the largest ever recorded in the region.  The scientists also uncovered  seismic signals called aposVery Long Periodapos signals . The signals were coming from an area about  miles off the eastern coast of Mayotte. There were no signs of volcanic activity in the area, but they suspected it could be the cause of sounds. They took measurements of the signals from the island, Madagascar and Africa. They they noticed Mayotteaposs islandaposs surface had lowered by seven inches, which was likely caused by the wave of earthquakes.  The researchers were able to come up with a reconstruction of what happened, discovering the new underwater volcano. They say the first phase of the volcanoaposs formation involved magma rising from a reservoir in the Earthaposs mantle, which opened a channel in the ocean floor to allow it to flow out. One the volcano had formed, the quake activity dropped and Mayotteaposs surface lowered. The VLP signals then began, which the researchers say they have interpreted as a sign that the deep magma chamber that created the underwater volcano was collapsing. Last May, an oceanographic survey revealed there was indeed a new underwater volcano off the coat of Mayotte.

title: dee must bounce back and secure second spot says keeper hamilton
story: Dundee goalkeeper Jack Hamilton insists it is vitally important they quickly bounce back from defeat to Inverness and secure second spot in the Championship.The Dark Blues fell to fourth in the table after a - defeat to second-placed ICT at Dens on Saturday and now lag six points behind the Highlanders.Sitting in the final promotion play-off spot is far from where the Dee would have hoped to have been at this stage of the season.However, Hamilton admits they can only look at themselves to recty that and make their path to any potential push for Premiership promotion clear as early as possible.“You don’t want to be coming towards the end of the season wondering where you’ll finish. Ideally, we’ve got to be finishing second,” he said.“It takes out that extra two games in the play-offs and that’s where we want to be, that’s what we’re looking towards and realistically we’ve got the squad to do that.“We’ve got to look to win every game and it’s down to us really. Dundee United are sitting  points ahead so,they weren’t to win the league it’d be a disaster on their part.“We’ll just concentrate on ourselves. There’s no point looking at anybody , each week we don’t look at other results thinking ‘whatwe do this and that’ we just focus on our own performances and how we’re going to beat teams.“We need to start getting three points on the board again.”Ending their four-match unbeaten run, particularly after a morale-boosting derby draw the weekend previous, with a loss against the Caley Jags stung for Dundee and Hamilton.And the -year-old is determined to put that right as soon as possible with three points when third-placed Ayr United come to town on Saturday.The former Hearts man added: “It was really disappointing off the back of a good run of games and it just wasn’t acceptable.“We started sloppy and it just continued throughout. It wasn’t a nice one on Saturday.“In the derby, in the second half in particular, I thought the boys were magnicent and then you’re looking for the same as that against Inverness on Saturday but we started off poorly and that just continued throughout the game. vw, px"  “We knew what they were all about, they’re sitting second in the league and they’re a good side.“They were a team we had to beat but we’ll sit down and watch the game and we’ll see where we went wrong.“We’ve got to recty that in the next game looking forward.“We just need to get back to the second half of the derby, that’s the performance we’re capable of and we’ve got a right good team in that dressing-room – it’s just about getting that consistency and kicking on from there.“Everybody out there on the pitch knows how good we are inidually so it’s one of those ones where we are frustrated.Dundee - Inverness: Dismal Dee drop to fourth with ICT defeat" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee---inverness-dismal-dee-drop-to-fourth-with-ict-defeat embed # secretXqUmxEai" data-secret"XqUmxEai" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“We need to assess the game and look to see where we can improve.“Going forward, we need to get the three points against Ayr.”And Hamilton knows they need to get the fans back on side after many voiced their displeasure on Saturday.“It’s not nice and you can feel and understand the supporters’ frustration.“They’re entitled to their opinion, quite rightly so because they support the team.“They want the highest possible achievement for Dundee and likewise so do we, so when things aren’t working out as we’d like they’re going to be frustrated.“We’ve got to do it for them as well as ourselves.”

title: dundee 0 2 inverness dismal dee drop to fourth with ict defeat
story: Dundee dropped to fourth in the Championship table as they fell to a - defeat to Inverness at Dens Park.First-half goals from Aaron Doran and James Keatings did the damage as John Robertson#s Caley Jags strengthened their grip on second spot.Ayr winning at Dunfermline meant the Dark Blues dropped to the fourth and final promotion play-off spot,  points behind leaders Dundee United.Dee boss James McPake stuck with the same line-up which earned a point in the Dundee derby with -year-old Fin Robertson starting in the middle of the park after a terric display at Tannadice.Inverness were the first to threaten but Nikolay Todorov could only head Miles Storey#s cross over the bar after three minutes.Caley skipper Carl Tremarco went closer on nine minutes as he got on the end of another Storey cross after a period of pressure. However, Dark Blues keeper Jack Hamilton gathered the header comfortably.Hamilton then made a smart stop from a whipped Keatings free-kick minutes later as the visitors continued to push for the opener.On  minutes Charlie Trafford forced a routine save out of Hamilton before, just a minute later, Inverness got the goal their play deserved.In acres of space down the right, full-back Shaun Rooney had the freedom of Dens Park to pick out Doran in the centre of the box and the Irish attacker duly lashed home from  yards.On  minutes, ICT were two to the good. From their own corner, Dundee compounded to lose possession and allowed the Highlanders to break.Former Dundee United man Keatings led the charge and finished the counter attack off himself, coolly slotting beyond a helpless Hamilton in the home goal.The Dark Blues huffed and puffed for the remainder of a dismal first half for them but were unable to lay a glove on Inverness as the boos rang out among the sizeable home support on the half-time whistle.Four minutes into the second period, Dundee forced Mark Ridgers into his first save of the afternoon as the ICT goalie stooped to turn Jordan Marshall#s long-range effort behind for a corner.Jordan McGhee was next to test Ridgers, firing in a dipping effort just before the hour mark, but the Caley stopper was able to gather.Moments later, Paul McGowan#s header from a deep Sean Mackie cross forced Ridgers to tip over as the Dee sought a way back into the contest.On  minutes, Kane Hemmings laid in Marshall but the left-back saw his effort from  yards deflected behind.Inverness# front four continued to look threatening but, largely, the Dee defence kept them quiet in the second .However, McPake#s men were unable to carve a way through an organised ICT defence with the rookie boss cutting a frustrated and under-pressure figure throughout.With Ayr and Dunfermline to face next, Dundee will certainly need to perform a lot betterthey are to stay in the mix for the promotion play-offs come the end of the season.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, Meekings , McGhee, Marshall Robertson, Dorrans, McGowan, MackieJohnson , Hemmings.Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Byrne, Moore and Cameron.Inverness XI : RidgersRooney, Donaldson, McHattie, TremarcoTrafford , Vincent StoreyKeatings Doran Todorov .Subs not used: Mackay , McCart, Curry and MacGregor.Referee: Don Robertson.Att: ,.

title: dundee set to close in on pre contract deals
story: Dundee manager James McPake says there are no signings “imminent” at the club ahead of the weekend’s clash with Ayr United.However, he did admit the club are close to two pre-contract agreements, with one believed to be with Inverness right-back Shaun Rooney.The Dens gaffer said: “I must have had easily over  phone calls over the last week – names from everywhere. But there’s genuinely nothing imminent.”Despite no incomings being imminent, James is keen for fans of the club not to take that for inaction behind the scenes.He added: “We don’t want six or seven signings every window. We need to keep building every window – looking to add and get stronger with every one.“We’re fourth in the league which isn’t great but it’s a process and we need to believe in what we’re trying to do.“I’d be quite happy keeping this squad and adding a couple.“We need to make sure we’re in the play-offs with a chance to get to the Premiership and we’re looking to build a team that can compete there.“We’ll hopefully get a couple of pre-contracts done with a view to next season.”One name that has been linked with a move back to the club this month is former Dee favourite Craig Wighton.“I loved working with Wighty when he was here,” said James.“I know his character and his talent. He’s training with the reserves at Hearts but there’s nothing happening with that. Will it  I’m genuinely not sure.“Wighty got put to us at the start of the season. He’s one we’re aware of and know very well but he’s a Hearts player at the minute.” vw, px"  Meanwhile, the Dens boss expects to have Graham Dorrans available for Saturday’s match against Ayr after he spoke with MK Dons at the start of the week.Dorrans scored his first, and so far only goal for Dundee in the derby at Tannadice on December  .“He’s trained very well over the last two days,” James added.“If he’s here come the weekend, he’ll be involved. My opinion hasn’t changed – I think he will be. That’s how I’ve felt all along unless something drastically changes.“I hope that’s not my heart ruling my head.“He’s been really professional in the way he’s dealt with it.“He’s an experienced player with good character. He still looks very committed in training.“He’s key to what we’re trying to do but we knew when we signed him that this might happen.“We’re prepared for whatever happens. title: mcpake demands dark blues take the game to ayr in crucial clash
story: James McPake has urged his Dundee players to “take the game” to Ayr United this weekend after failing to do so last time out against Inverness.The Dark Blues fell to a dispiriting defeat to the Highlanders at Dens Park on Saturday to fall six points behind the second-placed side.That came after the team gave themselves a boost with an impressive second-half display against runaway league leaders Dundee United after a run of three without defeat.This weekend they have a chance to get back on track as they host the third-placed Honest Men where victory would see them move back up the table.However, James knows his outfit will have to be far better than they showed last time out.He said: “Looking back, we didn’t start the game anywhere near how we should have done.“The confidence should have been there and, at home, you need to be more positive and take the game to the other team.“Inverness are second in the league for a reason – they are a decent enough side – but we were really poor.“I didn’t see it coming.“It was the same  that had done so well at Partick and then down the road as well. vw, px"  “We didn’t anticipate that happening but it has occurred before and we have managed to recover from it.“That has to be at the forefront of our minds now, getting it right this weekend against Ayr United.”He added: “It is frustrating.“The dficult thing to put your finger on is that we did not make signicant changes.“You can perhaps weigh it up when you have chopped and changed and ask: ‘Were we poor because we brought in four players ’“It was the same team against Inverness so we can’t do that.“They were better than us – simple as that.“They had a two-goal lead and were very comfortable.“In the second half we were a bit better but it’s easier to be better when you are - down and have to take the game to a team. I said as much to our players so we are not taking positives from that.“We have been here before and come back from a poor performance before. We need to do it again.“We can’t afford to be so up and down as a team.”The majority of Dundee’s low points this season have come on their own patch.The poor defeat to Inverness added to a list that includes bad days as hosts to Dundee United, Partick, Queen of the South and League Two Elgin City.However, James doesn’t feel there is an issue for players playing at Dens Park.“I was never big on that,” he added. “I didn’t feel that as a player. vw, px"  “The basic thing that supporters want to see is people going out there and working hard.“For  to  minutes, Inverness were much better than us and, by then, the game was effectively done as far as they were concerned as they had a lead and sat back off the match.“They were right to do that and it happened up there as well. They are really good at it.“You know that teams come here and look to get through the first  minutes or so and look to get the crowd turned against us.“That happens at clubs that have quite a bit of support.“But I genuinely don’t buy into the view that there is this big stigma or a big problem about playing at Dens.“I don’t get it and it should be the opposite because when you get it right and you get the fans right behind you it is a really good place to play.“It flips and becomes a good place to play football.“The atmosphere can be really good but I have said it before and I will say it again – we need to give them something back.”

title: third blaze in a matter of weeks at multi storey block of flats in perth
story: Fire crews were called out to a Perth multi-storey for the third time in weeks last night.The blaze, in a communal area, was quickly extinguished by firefighters and there was no need to evacuate the building on Thursday on this occasion.Emergency services were called to the block on Pomarium Street just before pm and police sealed off surrounding streets to allow five fire engines to reach the scene and tackle the incident.The outbreak was quickly under control and a spokesman for the fire and rescue services said: #We got the call at .pm last night that there was a fire in a block of flats in Pomarium Street and in a communal area.#There were four appliances there and a height appliance. It was put out quickly and we stepped down at .pm so it was only  minutes.#Only one hose rail jet was used to put the fire out.#Firefighters were also called out to blazes at the multi-storey block just before Christmas and again on Sunday, January .One resident said of last night#s incident: “We had the bathroom window open and the smoke started coming in. My we is choking.“It was just last week they were here. It’s getting beyond a joke.”Around  residents had to flee their homes because of last Sunday’s fire and were evacuated to a nearby hotel after a fire broke out in their building.Eight appliances from Perth, Dundee, and Auchterarder attended the blaze at the flats in last week#s outbreak which took place  shortly after pm.The adjacent Perth bus station was closed in order to be used as a staging point for other emergency services vehicles.A Police Scotland spokeswoman confirmed that they were in attendance to last night#s latest blaze and said: #It was a fire service led incident.#We were there to to assist with the surrounding roads.#

title: aberdeen community centre boss hails councils decision not to change the way they are run
story: An Aberdeen community centre chief today said centres have been “vindicated” following a climbdown by city councillors over how they are run.Aberdeen City Council was accused of trying to take “too much control” of the city’s  community centres and  learning centres and how they operate day-to-day.People from several centres across the city attended a meeting at the Town House yesterday, where councillors met to discuss the controversial proposals on the table.The agreement put forward by officers suggested compelling centres to achieve goals laid out by the council’s local outcome improvement plan .However, community centre leaders hit out at the plans, telling elected members the plan amounted to “micro-management”, leaving centres with less independence to run the services they provide.Following a debate lasting around three hours, John Wheeler, the council’s operational delivery committee convener, agreed to make changes to several of the proposals.This included throwing out a plan to replace the existing leases and management agreements with three-year leases and instead keeping the lease period as  years.This followed criticism from community centre chiefs who said they would not be able to apply for extended funding on shorter-term leases.A decision was also made to throw out formal adherence to the goals laid out in the LOIP.Speaking to the Evening Express after the meeting, Mr Wheeler said the strength of the deputations from the centres, plus ongoing discussions with officers, had convinced him the plans needed altering.He said: “I hope what we’ve got is something that will help develop stronger relationships with community centres and give them some certainty over the funding they had concerns about.”Paul O’Connor, chairman of Inchgarth Community Centre, said representatives felt “vindicated” by yesterday’s decision.He added: “We made the case clearly and concisely that the best people to make decisions for local community centres are those who are living and working there.“I’m happy the council have also agreed to extend the lease. It’s a common sense approach and will satisfy anyone who wishes to get extended funding.”However, Mr O’Connor said the latest debacle “begs the question” why community centres were put through the process in the first place.He added: “This has to be the last time we’re subjected to this.“We welcome the city council to work in partnership as equals in the full understanding we’re independent, autonomous organisations.“The people who work in these facilities are delivering outstanding services, value for money and opportunities for the wellbeing of everyone in the community.“We’ve been vindicated in our position and we thank Aberdeen City Council for listening.”Mr Wheeler reassured community centres they would not have to enter back into consultation again in the coming years.He said: “There was really extensive consultation with the community centres over a number of months.“And I would say that will certainly be it for the coming years.“We won’t need to enter back into consultation.”

title: end of an era as aecc arena be flattened
story: Work to knock down Aberdeen#s former exhibition centre is expected to begin in the coming weeks.Aberdeen City Council submitted a building warrant to demolish existing buildings at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centrein Bridge of Don, alongside agents Fairhurst.The site is no longer in use following the opening of the PJ Live arena in August last year.The multi-million-pound state-of-the-art event complex, which is in Bucksburn, now hosts all major events. vw, px"  The AECC first opened its doors in  and comprised of conference facilities and a multi-purpose arena.It has now been permanently closed.A building warrant was submitted in September to demolish buildings at the site including the main arena, which has now been approved by the local authority.Aberdeen City Council co-leader Douglas Lumsden said now the building warrant has been granted, the “intention” would be for that work to start “immediately”.He added: “That might include internal works first which people won’t be able to see.”As well as the removal of the old main arena building, the covered walkway that connects to the section of the conference centre next to the Holiday Inn Express will also be removed.It is expected that the value of the work to be undertaken will be around £,.The warrant has an expiry date of January   and all work must be completed by then.It is understood that the remaining conference centre will be retained as well as the nearby park-and-ride facility.Talks regarding the future use of the site are still ongoing.Plans were previously submitted to the local authority by developers Henry Boot in May  for the land, which hoped to create a mixed use development including approximately  residential units, properties for commercial and business use, a recycling centre and park-and-ride facility.The application is still pending and there was a number of documents uploaded on to the site in , along with a letter of objection received last year.It stated: “The site would have been better used as a new north-east HQ and training hub for Police Scotland with Queen Street being disposed of.“There would be ample space to create a specialist training facility, which Police Scotland does not have anywhere north of the central belt.”Discussions have also been under way with the King’s Community Church over the site, with the church keen to move from its base on King Street.The church began in  with a small gathering before it moved to the city centre church in  where it has remained.An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “A building warrant to demolish the arena at the old AECC and a covered walkway to the adjacent hotel has been approved by the planning authority.”

title: hundreds of kids get helping hand from north east charity
story: A north-east social care charity has provided support to hundreds of children in the last year.VSA provided guidance and aid to youngsters with disabilities or experiencing situations such as a family breakdown.A total of  children were given one-to-one counselling, while  youngsters with additional support needs were also given help.VSA organised , visits through its dedicated contact centre, which helps children going through a family breakdown by helping them contact a parent they no longer live with.And the charity won six Scottish Qualications Authority awards last year for its work with young people.School-based counselling is another of the charity’s services, which operates at Northfield, St Machar and Hazlehead Academies.Anna Garden, VSA’s director of children and family services, said: “We work closely with families, the local authority and other third sector partners to determine need and deliver services across the city.“We work from a strengths-based approach and consult with children and families to shape the design and delivery of future service provision.“We also have a contact centre which provides supported contact for children who have been affected by parental separation.“Where there is initial acrimony after separation, the contact centre acts as a neutral venue to facilitate contact with the non-resident parents.”She added: “We also have services for children with disabilities – after-school care for children with disabilities – offering a higher staff ratio than the universal services. The after-school club provision allows wraparound care provision for children with disabilities so their parents can maintain employment.”Aberdeen City Council’s education convener Councillor John Wheeler praised the charity’s work with young people across the region.He said: “I fully recognise the importance VSA has across the city. The charity does tremendous work in all the dferent areas.”

title: mystery 80000 cash gift lets aberdeen cricketer solo nqweni fly home to south africa
story: An Aberdeen cricket star who was struck down by a rare illness will be able tohome after an anonymous benefactor stepped in to fund his journey.Aberdeenshire Cricket Club player Solo Nqweni, , contracted Guillain Barre Syndrome last summer and was left unable to walk, talk or breathe unaided.The South African has spent months in hospital, far from home and his baby son – who was born just weeks before Solo travelled to the north-east.Last week, he was deemed well enough to fly home – but only with medical support – leaving him and his family facing a bill of around £,.A fundraiser was set up by his agent Rob Humphries, raising more than £, in three days.But now an anonymous donor has come forward to cover the remainder – reuniting the star with his little boy.And Solo’s family and friends hope he couldhome as early as this weekend.Rob, who arranged Solo’s move to the north-east through his firm World Sports Xchange, said: “Solo, the entire Nqweni family, the cricketing community at large and World Sports Xchange wish to thank every person that has donated, shared links on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and written or read about Solo’s story. We are truly touched by the overwhelming support as this would not have been achieved so soon.“We are eternally grateful for the kindness and generosity of spirit shown.“Aberdeenshire Cricket Club, Cricket South Africa, the incredible medical team at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, World Sports Xchange and the Nqweni family have provided Solo with such wonderful support and their efforts cannot be overstated.”Solo was in intensive care for three months before being transferred to the neurological ward at ARI.Members of his family made the trip from South Africa in shts to ensure someone was always by Solo’s side.He recovered enough of his speech to send a video message to his country’s rugby stars as they won last year’s World Cup.And he was well enough to meet England cricketer Ben Stokes, who visited when he was in the city for the Sports Personality of the Year awards.

title: north east reindeer farm closes after visit from council health and safety inspectors
story: A north-east reindeer farm is set to close its doors following a visit from health and safety officials.Aberdeenshire Council carried out an inspection at Ythanbank Reindeer after receiving a complaint.Officials gave advice to the owners of the centre but bosses have now announced it is to close as a result of the visit.In a statement, Ythanbank Reindeer said: “Aberdeenshire Council visited us and created a chain of events that means the council will not allow us to open again in our current format without installing warm hot running water hand-washing at ious locations throughout the property at prohibitive cost, or double fencing all animals and keeping the public at least one metre from them, which we refuse to do among many other demands.“We have decided not to spend the money to implement needless changes .”Although the facility is closed to the public, the reindeer and donkeys will continue to live at the centre.A spokesman for Aberdeenshire Council said: “During a visit to the business in December, the owner was provided with proportionate advice for its  activities on the provision of appropriate hand-wash facilities to safeguard visitors in line with guidance from the Health and Safety Executive.“The owner was also reminded of the mandatory requirements for the correct labelling of re-packaged confectionery to safeguard consumers who may have allergies.“While there have been no incidents at the site, public health is of paramount importance, particularly when people could become infected by micro-organisms such as E. coli O through direct contact with contaminated animals or contact with an environment contaminated with animal faeces where necessary protections aren’t in place.“We are sorry to hear the business feels it cannot continue its festive programme and we remain open to further discussion to seea way forward can be found.”

title: union terrace to shut one way for 11 months
story: A major Aberdeen street is to become one-way to traffic for almost a year while work is undertaken on the revamp of Union Terrace Gardens.From January , traffic will be permitted to travel northbound on Union Terrace from Union Street to Rosemount Viaduct, with the restriction expected to be in place until mid-November.This means motorists will still be able to travel from Union Street towards HMT, but not the reverse.Council bosses say a one-way system is needed to maintain a #safe working environment# during the next phase of the programme, which includes balustrade strengthening, the replacement of the existing arches , slab reinforcement and resurfacing.Contractor Balfour Beatty has been appointed to deliver the £. million project, with the gardens expected to reopen in summer .Councillor Marie Boulton, spokeswoman for the City Centre Masterplanproject, said: “We appreciate that a one-way system on Union Terrace may inconvenience some travellers, however during construction we must put the safety of workers and the public first.“There is a huge prize to be won. The works will enhance Union Terrace Gardens’ existing heritage features and provide a  for new elements that will greatly improve access and amenity, creating an inclusive garden for the st Century.“This is yet another milestone in the transformation our city centre and is to be welcomed as another step towards making Aberdeen an even more attractive place to visit, work and live.”The council has been liaising with bus operators and revised service timetables have been drawn up by both First Aberdeen and Stagecoach.

title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#

We hope this will remove a barrier to new members joining, as they will no longer have to provide their own equipment. On behalf of the team, we thank the Scottish Salmon Company for its kind donation.#Volunteers are being offered a chance to work off some of the seasonal over eating, as a work party is held at Tarbert Castle.Meeting at am tomorrow , the group will set about planting trees and removing brambles until around lunchtime.The perfect opportunity to catch up following the festivities, all willing to help will be made welcome and tea and coffee will be on offer to the hard working volunteers.A #Scandinavian# approach to self-sufficiency is being proposed by Craignish Community Council.With Argyll and Bute Council being unable extend their gritting areas, community council members picked up bags of grit from the council depot.
